awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC:  Penn State University Phase III: Center for e-Design
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for e-Design (CED) is an NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) that works with its member organizations to research and advance solutions to complex problems associated with the innovation, design, production, distribution, and sustainment of innovative and high quality products and systems, that minimize costs and are responsive to the rapidly changing marketplace.  Concurrent design of products and supporting processes; improved integration and collaboration among people, tools, and information; process improvements; knowledge capture and reuse; and automated/assisted decision-making are just some of the strategies employed. The Center for e-Design has research sites in place at six universities (Iowa State University, the University of Massachusetts Amherst, the University of Buffalo, Brigham Young University, Oregon State University, and Wayne State University). This project adds The Pennsylvania State University (Penn State), a seventh university, to the research sites in the Center.  Penn State brings expertise from a diverse interdisciplinary team of researchers from several departments, colleges, university centers and institutes.  The primary contribution of the Penn State team will include the following areas: crowd-based design, big data analytics, design theory and innovation, collaborative design, design optimization, additive manufacturing, smart manufacturing, and model-based enterprise.

The Center for e-Design's activities are organized around three major efforts which deliver value to its industry/government partners: 1) Fundamental Research focuses on creating tools, methods, and technologies to address industry relevant needs in e-tools-enabled product development and realization including enabling information infrastructure; conceptual design tools; multidisciplinary constraint management and optimization; and virtual prototyping and simulation;  2) Research Test Bed focuses on integration of interdisciplinary research activities to validate developed tools, methods, and technologies and establish a common framework for multiple applications while fostering collaboration between academic and industry research projects; and 3) Engineering Education and Technology Transfer, which focuses on educating a new cadre of engineers and scientists proficient in e-design and rapidly transferring research results into usable applications for industry and government.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Center for e-Design is an NSF industry university cooperative research center comprised of seven universities working closely with numerous industrial companies and government organizations. The Center was established in 2003 to create new design paradigms and electronic design tools that assist in generating high-quality products and systems at a reduced cost while also reducing the time to market associated with the design and realization of complex engineered products and systems. The research efforts of the Center for e-Design support the basic premise that information is the lifeblood of an enterprise and that collaboration is what seamlessly integrates all aspects of a product?s lifecycle.

The Center was first established by the University of Pittsburgh (lead) and the University of Massachusetts Amherst in 2003. A number of university sites were added to the Center over its 18 years.  The lead site moved over the years, from the University to Pittsburgh to Virginia Polytechnic Institute, Iowa State University, and to the Penn State University due to career advancement of Dr. Janis Terpenny who she served as the Center director, with distinction, for most of the life of the Center. In total, there have been 11 universities who participated in the center (UMass-Amherst, University of Pittsburgh, Virginia Tech, University of Central Florida, Carnegie Mellon University, Iowa State University, Penn State, Brigham Young University, University of Buffalo, University of Illinois, and Oregon State University) and over 30 members from a variety of industries and government agencies. 

Over the 18-year life of the Center, over 200 collaborative projects have been executed resulting in several patents, nearly 600 publications, millions of dollars in cost savings, and hundreds of students trained in research and development activities. The basic research performed in the Center formed the foundation for many larger integrations and collaborations with the ManufacturingUSA Innovation Institutes that advanced the technology readiness of the research and resulted in additional training opportunities for students and cost savings for the industry partners.

Graduation from the NSF IUCRC program presents the next opportunity for the Center. The core research and development thrust areas and technical direction is poised to continue long into the future. Research in digital design and manufacturing has become increasingly important as the United States manufacturing sector moves into the digital age.

"Personally, it is the human elements that I am most proud of.  So many students (graduate and undergraduate) as well as post-doctoral fellows, experienced an environment of collaboration across disciplines, with openness and sharing, and real experiences and insights that cannot be gained any other way than with partners in industry... access to expertise, insights, data, facilities, and more.  Likewise, faculty and industry partners gained so much... as colleagues and partners with common goals and understanding that could not have been possible otherwise." - Dr. Janis Terpenny


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: Daniel A Finke
